content:
The first attempted experiments for the formation of 3D MOFs in scCO2 were directed to the crystallization of the MIL-88B­(Fe) phase by reacting Fe­(NO3)3 and the dicarboxylate H2bdc (). The reaction was performed at 20 MPa and 333 K and required the addition of a 2% v/v of dioxane (). Moreover, an intensive cleaning step with ethanol to eliminate residual reagents contaminating the final product was necessary. Under solvothermal conditions, MIL-88B solids with general formula (M3+)3OX­(solvent)2(−O2C–R–CO2−)3]·nH2O·MeOH (M = Fe3+ or Cr3+; X = F–, OH–, Cl–, or –O2C–CH3), have been synthesized. These structures are typical examples of highly flexible MOFs in which the unit cell volume undergoes a reversible expansion from the closed (dehydrated) to the open (fully solvated) forms, with enormous changes in the volume of the unit cell. The XRD pattern of the precipitated sample was in agreement with the profile reported for the MIL-88B­(Cr) phase in ref (a). The elemental analysis indicated the probable precipitation in scCO2 of a compound with the general formula [Fe3O­(H2O)2OH­(bdc)3]. However, the end product was highly contaminated with residual Fe­(NO3)3 reagent and contained noticeable amounts of water. As expected, N2 adsorption gave a low surface area value for this compound on the order of 60 m2·g–1 due to the closed-pore characteristics of the dry structure. SEM images showed spindle-shaped elongated crystals of 0.5–2 μm (), morphology similar to that observed for microwave-assisted solvothermally precipitated MIL-88B­(Fe) crystals.

ZIF-8

In a second series of experiments, ZIF-8, with formulas [Zn­(2-mim)2] (2-mim = methylimidazole) and sodalite topology, was synthesized in pure scCO2 from Zn­(acac)2 and H2-mim (). ZIF-8 is currently one of the most extensively investigated zeolitic imidazole frameworks (ZIFs), a subclass of MOFs. Using scCO2 as the exclusive synthesis medium, the straight precipitation of an empty-pore ZIF-8 nanopowder was successfully achieved in a 10 h run at 333 K (), as shown by the agreement between the XRD patterns of the synthesized and published single crystal data (b). However, the development of an extra peak at 2θ = 11.1° indicates the simultaneous formation of ZIF-8 and the kinetically favored phase described as ZIF-L. Under similar experimental conditions, to precipitate pure ZIF-8, the temperature must be decreased to 313 K in the 10 h run (b). The reversible type I isotherm was recorded for these samples. The micropore surface area of the as-synthesized sample at 313 K was on the order of 1200 m2·g–1, comparable to the reported value in the literature for conventionally precipitated products. In the supercritical procedure, from the two used reagents, only Zn­(acac)2 had a significant solubility in scCO2. However, the reaction with 2-Hmim took place with a high yield, even at the soft conditions of 313 K. Previous studies have shown that the formation of ZIF-8 crystals occurs through tetranuclear and related oligomeric Zn2+ species, in which the cations are bridged by 2-mim ligands. Therefore, one possible explanation for the mechanism occurring in scCO2 is that the reaction goes through the formation of low molecular weight soluble species involving both reagents, which assembled to form the intermediate kinetic amorphous phase. Indeed, this low degree of crystallinity was observed in the XRD pattern of a 1 h sample produced at 313 K (b). This diffractogram also showed the presence of an intermediate phase with an intense peak at ca. 2θ = 12°. SEM analysis indicated that the 1 h sample was mainly constituted by amorphous spherical particles that agglomerate in large units (a). However, a closed view showed the presence of some rhombohedral structures with smooth surfaces already developed (b), potentially corresponding to the metastable phase observed in the diffractogram recorded at 1 h (b). Further analysis at 10 h indicated the presence of large agglomerates of 50–200 μm (c), surprisingly depicting pores of 2–5 μm in diameter, which is a unique morphology described for the first time for this type of crystalline product. These macropores are likely formed in a top-down process from the agglomerated mass of crystals during the step of expansion and evacuation of the compressed CO2 trapped into the ZIF-8 structural pores and in the interparticle pore volume. Local magnification revealed that the macroscopic assemblies were constituted by cubic primary nanometric particles with crystal sizes on the order of 50–200 nm (d). A porous hierarchical microstructure is thus obtained, involving structural ZIF-8 micropores together with the described macropores. Such cellular structures have previously been observed in amorphous polymeric systems prepared using scCO2, but they are a novelty for crystalline coordination polymers. Hierarchical meso/microporous structures have been described for other MOFs precipitated in scCO2 but using complex setups with ionic liquids and/or surfactants.
clean_text:
MIL-88B(Fe)

The first attempted experiments for the formation of 3D MOFs in scCO2 were directed to the crystallization of the MIL-88B(Fe) phase by reacting Fe(NO3)3 and the dicarboxylate H2bdc (). The reaction was performed at 20 MPa and 333 K and required the addition of a 2% v/v of dioxane (). Moreover, an intensive cleaning step with ethanol to eliminate residual reagents contaminating the final product was necessary. Under solvothermal conditions, MIL-88B solids with general formula (M3+)3OX(solvent)2(-O2C-R-CO2-)3]⋅nH2O⋅MeOH (M = Fe3+ or Cr3+; X = F-, OH-, Cl-, or -O2C-CH3), have been synthesized. These structures are typical examples of highly flexible MOFs in which the unit cell volume undergoes a reversible expansion from the closed (dehydrated) to the open (fully solvated) forms, with enormous changes in the volume of the unit cell. The XRD pattern of the precipitated sample was in agreement with the profile reported for the MIL-88B(Cr) phase in ref  (a). The elemental analysis indicated the probable precipitation in scCO2 of a compound with the general formula [Fe3O(H2O)2OH(bdc)3]. However, the end product was highly contaminated with residual Fe(NO3)3 reagent and contained noticeable amounts of water. As expected, N2 adsorption gave a low surface area value for this compound on the order of 60 m2⋅g-1 due to the closed-pore characteristics of the dry structure. SEM images showed spindle-shaped elongated crystals of 0.5-2 μm (), morphology similar to that observed for microwave-assisted solvothermally precipitated MIL-88B(Fe) crystals. 

ZIF-8
